Enhancements on import functions

The functions can now import cron jobs with special strings (@hourly,
@daily etc.).

Also the URL has changed to /host/<host_id>/import and the function
has been moved to the hosts controller.

* 'feature/slack_alert' of https://github.com/mvlbarcelos/minicron:
  Feature Slack Alert.
  Doc fix and try and trigger automated docker hub build

# Conflicts:
#	minicron.gemspec

Improvements for import jobs function

Just to make sure we won't mess things up, I'm searching for 'minicron run'
from a job line and removing it. Could it happen that we import from a crontab
that was already edited by minicron? Who knows... but let's filter it.

Small changes on import jobs

Changed some functions arguments. There was a function receiving
an object when it used only the name.
Added some comments to the import jobs functions.

Button to import jobs

Added a button to import crontab jobs on the host page.
It will only appear if the host has no jobs in the database.

The button will make a call to '/jobs/import/<host_id>'.

Import existing crontab jobs

Added a function to import the crontabs for a given host.
It will only import the jobs for the user registered to the host.

The function will get an array of jobs, save them to the database
and then will save their schedules to the database. It will then
return to the host page.

Read and parse a crontab file

Added functions to read and parse a crontab file.
The function read all the jobs from a crontab file (uses crontab -l)
and returns an array with a hash of jobs consisting of name, command
and schedule.
Doc fix and try and trigger automated docker hub build

* trek10inc-develop:
  Clarify explanation and add 30 second post buffer also
  A more generous job buffer period
Clarify explanation and add 30 second post buffer also

A more generous job buffer period

There are some problems with remote servers be a few seconds fast or
slow, this makes the job buffer period a bit more flexible. If a remote
client was fast, it was possible that a job would ‚Äúsucceed‚Äù but then an
alert would be sent because a job execution ‚Äúmissed‚Äù (even though it
was just early).
